items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels have fallen on the Cole and Dorcan Brook but have the potential to rise again following isolated rainfall forecast today. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible this afternoon, 21 September 2023, especially in the Lower Stratton area. Scattered showers are forecast in the area throughout this afternoon into evening. Levels may respond on the Cole and Dorcan Brook if these showers fall on the Lower Stratton area.

Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening, 21 September 2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
River levels have been falling since the early hours of Thursday 21st September.
No further flooding to properties and roads is expected in the area, however there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days.
Further isolated showers forecast for Thursday and Friday is not expected to make river levels rise again.
We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts and will issue any new flood message when needed.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent heavy rainfall and will remain high for several days.
River levels are high but steady at the Far Sawrey; Jeffy Knotts; Miller Bridge; Newby Bridge gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 22/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent heavy rainfall and will remain so for several days.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.River levels also remain high at the Keswick Campsite; Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9:00am on 22/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level, and are likely to remain high for several days.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site 
River levels also remain high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 22/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
Flooding remains possible at Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, today.

Showers are clearing but further rain may keep river levels high for a few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 21:00 on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are now falling steadily this evening 20/09/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

The river level has fallen below Flood Alert at the Pooley Bridge gauge, however river levels remain high.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are forecast at the Mordiford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. 
Peaks:- 
Hay on Wye 2.63m last night, 
Bredwardine 4.37m last night, 
Belmont 4.34m this morning, 
Old Wye Bridge 3.90m this morning,
Mordiford 3.85m this morning
Predicted peaks:-
Ross on Wye 3.2m to 3.4m this afternoon, 
We expect river levels to remain high into Friday 22/09/2023. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 19:00 today, 21/09/2021, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
River levels are now returning to normal at the Botcherby Bridge; Eden Valley Flows; Linstock; Sheepmount gauge.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

No further flooding to properties and roads is expected in the area, however there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days.
Further isolated showers forecast for Thursday and Friday is not expected to make river levels rise again.
We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts and will issue any new flood message when needed.

River levels are rising at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue . We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. 
Predicted Peaks:- 
Ross on Wye 3.2m to 3.4m this afternoon, 
Lydbrook 3.8m to 4.0m  this evening. 
We expect river levels to remain high into Friday 22/09/2023. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 19:00 today, 21/09/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but falling on the Bear Brook and tributaries as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today especially in the Aylesbury area. Scattered showers are possible in the area throughout this afternoon into evening. Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

 This message will be updated this evening, 21 September 2023, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Monks Brook is now falling. Today (Thursday 21/09/2023), showery conditions are expected to affect Hampshire bringing up to 15mm of rainfall. If the heaviest rain affects the Monks Brook, the river is expected to rise a little but further flooding impacts are not currently expected. We continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information and will issue further advice if additional rainfall causes a significant rise in water levels.

Water levels in the River Blackwater remain high, but have peaked and are slowly falling after heavy rainfall overnight. The Romsey rain gauge recorded 41mm in the past 24 hours. Low lying land at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower may be flooded. Water levels will be high around the mill building at East Wellow. The weather forecast for today (21/09/2023) is for isolated scattered showers of 10-15mm which will clear overnight. There is low confidence in the location of the showers. If they occur in the Blackwater catchment, river levels may start to rise again. Property flooding is not expected. If drier conditions persist this afternoon, river levels will continue to fall. Isolated showers are forecast tomorrow (22/09/2023) but rainfall totals are less, 7-10mm. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river is free from reported blockages. Please ensure that any pumps used to help protect property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 19:00 on Thursday 21/09/2023.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Dee due to rainfall over the last few days, with more rain due over the next few days.

River levels are expected to remain high on 22/09/2023 and into next week. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee, with low lying land and footpaths around Farndon expected to be most affected.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 22/09/2023, or as the situation changes.
